revision.text:
[[File:The 3D model of Berlin.jpg|thumb|The 3D model of Berlin allows viewers to look at the city as it is now, as it once was, and as the city it might turn into in the future.]]
'''3D city models''' are digital models of urban areas that represent terrain surfaces, sites, buildings, vegetation, infrastructure and landscape elements in three-dimensional scale as well as related objects (e.g., city furniture) belonging to urban areas. Their components are described and represented by corresponding two-dimensional and three-dimensional spatial data and geo-referenced data. 3D city models support presentation, exploration, analysis, and management tasks in a large number of different application domains. In particular, 3D city models allow "for visually integrating heterogeneous geoinformation within a single framework and, therefore, create and manage complex urban information spaces." <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hpi.uni-potsdam.de/fileadmin/hpi/FG_Doellner/publications/2006/DBB06/CORP2006_doellner.pdf |title=J. Döllner, K. Baumann, H. Buchholz: ''Virtual 3D City Models as Foundation of Complex Urban Information Spaces''. 11th international conference on Urban Planning and Spatial Development in the Information Society (REAL CORP), (Manfred Schrenk, ed.), CORP – Competence Center of Urban and Regional Planning, pp. 107–112, 2006.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VwDSj9Yo_38 |title=Example video for 3D city models as complex information spaces}}</ref>
== Storage of 3D City Models == To store 3D city models, both file-based and database approaches are used. There is no single, unique representation schema due to the heterogeneity and diversity of 3d city model contents.
=== Encoding of Components === Components of 3D city models are encoded by common file and exchange formats for 2D raster-based GIS data (e.g., [[GeoTIFF]]), 2D vector-based GIS data (e.g., [[AutoCAD DXF]]), 3D models (e.g., [[.3DS]], [[Object file|.OBJ]]), and 3D scenes (e.g., [[Collada]], [[Keyhole Markup Language]]) such as supported by [[Computer-aided design|CAD]], [[GIS]], and [[computer graphics]] tools and systems. All components of a 3D city model have to be transformed into a common [[geographic coordinate system]].
=== Databases === A database for 3D city models stores its components in a hierarchically structured, multi-scale way, which allows for a stable and reliable data management and facilitates complex GIS modeling and analysis tasks. For example, the 3D City Database is a free 3D geo database to store, represent, and manage virtual 3D city models on top of a standard spatial relational database.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.3dcitydb.org/3dcitydb/welcome/ |title=3D City DB Web Site www.3dcitydb.org}}</ref> A database is required if 3D city models have to be continuously managed. 3D city model databases form a key element in 3D spatial data infrastructures that require support for storing, managing, maintenance, and distribution of 3D city model contents.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.virtualcitysystems.de/en/products/virtualcitydatabase |title=virtual city database for 3D city and landscape models}}</ref> Their implementation requires support of a multitude of formats (e.g., based on FME multi formats). As common application, geodata download portals can be set up for 3D city model contents (e.g., virtualcityWarehouse).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.virtualcitysystems.de/en/products/virtualcitywarehouse.html |title=virtualcityWarehouse |access-date=2014-07-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531190348/http://virtualcitysystems.de/en/products/virtualcitywarehouse.html |archive-date=2014-05-31 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
=== CityGML === The [[Open Geospatial Consortium]] (OGC) defines an explicit [[XML]]-based exchange format for 3D city models, [[CityGML]], which supports not only geometric descriptions of 3D city model components but also the specification of semantics and topology information.<ref>T. H. Kolbe: ''Representing and Exchanging 3D City Models with CityGML''. 3D Geo-Information Sciences, J. Lee, [[Sisi Zlatanova|S. Zlatanova]], W. Cartwright, G. Gartner, L. Meng, and M. P. Peterson, Eds. Springer Berlin Heidelberg, 2009, pp. 15–31</ref>
== Construction of 3D City Models ==
=== Level of Detail === 3D city models are typically constructed at various [[level of detail|levels of detail]] (LOD) to provide notions of multiple resolutions and at different levels of abstraction. Other metrics such as the level of spatio-semantic coherence and resolution of the texture can be considered a part of the LOD.<ref> {{cite journal |year=2014 |title=Formalisation of the level of detail in 3D city modelling |journal=Computers, Environment and Urban Systems |volume=48 |issue=1 |pages=1–15 |doi=10.1016/j.compenvurbsys.2014.05.004 |last1=Biljecki |first1=F. |last2=Ledoux |first2=H. |last3=Stoter |first3=J. |last4=Zhao |first4=J. }}</ref> For example, [[CityGML]] defines five LODs for building models: * LOD 0: [[2.5D]] footprints * LOD 1: Buildings represented by block models (usually extruded footprints) * LOD 2: Building models with standard roof structures * LOD 3: Detailed (architectural) building models * LOD 4: LOD 3 building models supplemented with interior features.
There exist also approaches to generalize a given detailed 3D city model by means of automated generalization.<ref>T. Glander, J. Döllner: ''Techniques for Generalizing Building Geometry of Complex Virtual 3D City Models''. Advances in 3D Geoinformation Systems, (Peter van Oosterom and [[Sisi Zlatanova]] and Friso Penninga and Elfriede M. Fendel, ed.), Lecture Notes in Geoinformation and Cartography, Springer, pp. 381–400, 2008.</ref> For example, a hierarchical road network (e.g., [[OpenStreetMap]]) can be used to group 3D city model components into "cells"; each cell is abstracted by aggregating and merging contained components.
=== GIS Data === [[GIS]] data provide the base information to build a 3D city model such as by digital terrain models, road networks, land use maps, and related geo-referenced data. GIS data also includes cadastral data that can be converted into simple 3D models as, for example, in the case of extruded building footprints. Core components of 3D city models form [[digital terrain model]]s (DTM) represented, for example, by TINs or grids.
=== CAD Data === Typical sources of data for 3D city model also include [[Computer-aided design|CAD]] models of buildings, sites, and infrastructure elements. They provide a high level of detail, possible not required by 3D city model applications, but can be incorporated either by exporting their geometry or as encapsulated objects.
=== BIM Data === [[Building information modeling|Building information models]] represent another category of geo-spatial data that can be integrated into a 3D city model providing the highest level of detail for building components.
=== Integration at Visualization Level === Complex 3D city models typically are based on different sources of geodata such as geodata from GIS, building and site models from CAD and BIM. It is one of their core properties to establish a common reference frame for heterogeneous geo-spatial and geo-referenced data, i.e., the data need not to be merged or fusioned based on one common data model or schema. The integration is possible by sharing a common geo-coordinate system at the visualization level.<ref>J. Döllner, B. Hagedorn: ''Integrating Urban GIS, CAD, and BIM Data By Service-Based Virtual 3D City-Models''. Urban and Regional Data Management: UDMS 2007 Annual, (Massimo Rumor and Volker Coors and Elfriede M. Fendel and [[Sisi Zlatanova]], ed.), Taylor & Francis Ltd., Stuttgart, Germany, pp. 157–170, 2007.</ref>
=== Building Reconstruction === The simplest form of building model construction consist in extruding the footprint polygons of buildings, e.g., taken from the cadaster, by pre-compute average heights. In practice, 3D models of buildings of urban regions are generated based on capturing and analyzing 3D [[point cloud]]s (e.g., sampled by terrestrial or aerial [[3D scanning|laser scanning]]) or by photogrammetric approaches. To achieve a high percentage of geometrically and topologically correct 3D building models, digital terrain surfaces and 2D footprint polygons are required by automated building [[3D reconstruction|reconstruction]] tools such as BREC.<ref>http://www.virtualcitysystems.de/en/products/buildingreconstruction</ref> One key challenge is to find building parts with their corresponding roof geometry. "Since fully automatic image understanding is very hard to solve, semi-automatic components are usually required to at least support the recognition of very complex buildings by a human operator."<ref>N. Haala, M. Kada: [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Fatemeh_Sadeghi/post/Can_anyone_suggest_to_me_the_possible_methods_to_semantically_enrich_3D_city_model/attachment/59d632fbc49f478072ea1e47/AS%3A273638396235777%401442251886039/download/An+update+on+automatic+3D+building+reconstruction.pdf An update on automatic 3D building reconstruction]. ISPRS Journal of Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing 65 (2010), 570–580.</ref> Statistical approaches are common for roof reconstruction based on airborne laser scanning point clouds. <ref>H. Huang, C. Brenner, M. Sester: ''3D building roof reconstruction from point clouds via generative models''. GIS 2011: 16-24.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://dx.doi.org/10.13140/RG.2.1.2269.8000 |title=K. Hammoudi: ''Contributions to the 3D city modeling: 3D polyhedral building model reconstruction from aerial images and 3D facade modeling from terrestrial 3D point cloud and images''. Ph.D. thesis in signal and image processing, Université Paris-Est, 234p., 2011.}}</ref>
Fully automated processes exist to generate LOD1 and LOD2 building models for large regions. For example, the Bavarian Office for Surveying and Spatial Information is responsible for about 8 million building models at LOD1 and LOD2.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://virtualcitysystems.de/en/references.html#projects |title=Bavarian LOD2 Building Model Project |access-date=2014-07-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531173221/http://virtualcitysystems.de/en/references.html#projects |archive-date=2014-05-31 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Visualization of 3D City Models == The [[Visualization (computer graphics)|visualization]] of 3D city models represents a core functionality required for interactive applications and systems based on 3D city models.
=== Real-Time Rendering of 3D City Models === Providing high quality visualization of massive 3D city models in a scalable, fast, and cost efficient manner is still a challenging task due to the complexity in terms of 3D geometry and [[texture mapping|textures]] of 3D city models. [[Real-time rendering]] provides a large number of specialized 3D rendering techniques for 3D city models. Examples of specialized real-time 3D rendering include: * Real-time 3D rendering of road networks on high resolution terrain models.<ref>M. Vaaraniemi, M. Treib, R. Westermann: ''High-Quality Cartographic Roads on High-Resolution DEMs.'' Journal of WSCG 19(2):41-48, 2011.</ref> * Real-time 3D rendering of water surfaces with cartography-oriented design.<ref> A. Semmo et al.: ''[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Matthias_Trapp/publication/241686838_Real-Time_Rendering_of_Water_Surfaces_with_Cartography-Oriented_Design/links/0deec51c9c3079b2b4000000.pdf Real-Time Rendering of Water Surfaces with Cartography-Oriented Design].'' Proceedings International Symposium on Computational Aesthetics in Graphics, Visualization, and Imaging (CAe), pp. 5–14, 2013.</ref> * Real-time 3D rendering of day and night sky phenomena.<ref>D. Limberger et al.: ''Single-Pass Rendering of Day and Night Sky Phenomena.'' Proceedings of the Vision, Modeling, and Visualization Workshop 2012, Eurographics Association, pp. 55-62, 2012.</ref> * Real-time 3D rendering of grid-based terrain models.<ref>F. Losasso, H. Hoppe: ''Geometry clipmaps: Terrain rendering using nested regular grids.'' ACM Trans. Graphics (SIGGRAPH), 23(3), 2004.</ref> * Real-time 3D rendering using different levels of abstraction, ranging between 2D map views and 3D views.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tU5d6WuSglk</ref> * Real-time 3D rendering of [[multiperspectivity|multiperspective]] views on 3D city models.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bT01QsZMYDE</ref><ref>http://www.hpi.uni-potsdam.de/doellner/publications/year/2014/2390/PSTD2014.html Multiperspective Views for 3D City Models</ref>
Real-time rendering algorithms and data structures are listed by the virtual terrain project.<ref>http://vterrain.org/LOD/Papers/</ref>
=== Service-Based Rendering of 3D City Models === [[Service-oriented architecture]]s (SOA) for visualizing 3D city models offer a separation of concerns into management and rendering and their interactive provision by client applications. For SOA-based approaches, 3D portrayal services<ref>http://www.opengeospatial.org/projects/initiatives/3dpie</ref> are required, whose main functionality represents the portrayal in the sense of 3D rendering and visualization.<ref>J. Klimke, J. Döllner: ''Service-oriented Visualization of Virtual 3D City Models''. Directions Magazine, 2012. http://www.directionsmag.com/articles/service-oriented-visualization-of-virtual-3d-city-models/226560</ref> SOA-based approaches can be distinguished into two main categories, currently discussed in the [[Open Geospatial Consortium]]:
* Web 3D Service (W3DS): This type of service handles geodata access and mapping to computer graphics primitives such as scene graphs with textured 3D geometry models as well as their delivery to the requesting client applications. The client applications are responsible for the 3D rendering of delivered scene graphs, i.e., they are responsible for the interactive display using their own 3D graphics hardware. * Web View Service (WVS): This type of service encapsulates the 3D rendering process for 3D city models at the server side. The server generates views of the 3D scene or intermediate, image-based representations (e.g., virtual panoramas or G-buffer cube maps<ref>J. Döllner, B. Hagedorn: ''[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Jan_Klimke/publication/254463533_Server-Based_Rendering_of_Large_3D_Scenes_for_Mobile_Devices_Using_G-Buffer_Cube_Maps/links/56c72b2f08ae0d3b1b65d517/Server-Based-Rendering-of-Large-3D-Scenes-for-Mobile-Devices-Using-G-Buffer-Cube-Maps.pdf Server-Based Rendering of Large 3D Scenes for Mobile Devices Using G-Buffer Cube Maps]''. Web3D '12 Proceedings of the 17th International Conference on 3D Web Technology, pp. 97-100, 2012.</ref>), which are streamed and uploaded to requesting client applications. The client applications are responsible for re-construction the 3D scene based on the intermediate representations. Client applications do not have to process 3D graphics data, but to provide management for loading, caching, and displaying the image-based representations of 3D scenes and do not have to process the original (and possibly large) 3D city model.
=== Map-Based Visualization === A map-based technique, the "smart map" approach, aims at providing "massive, virtual 3D city models on different platforms namely web browsers, smartphones or tablets, by means of an interactive map assembled from artificial oblique image tiles." <ref>J. Klimke et al.: "Scalable Multi-Platform Distribution of Spatial 3D Contents". ISPRS 8th 3D GeoInfo Conference & WG II/2 Workshop 27–29 November 2013, Istanbul, Turkey, (U. Isikdag, ed.), vol. II-2/W1, ISPRS Annals, ISPRS, pp. 193-200, 2013.</ref> The map tiles are synthesized by an automatic 3D rendering process of the 3D city model; the map tiles, generated for different levels-of-detail, are stored on the server. This way, the 3D rendering is completely performed on the server's side, simplifying access and usage of 3D city models. The 3D rendering process can apply advanced rendering techniques (e.g., global illumination and shadow calculation, illustrative rendering), but does not require client devices to have advanced 3D graphics hardware. Most importantly, the map-based approach allows for distributing and using complex 3D city models with having to stream the underlying data to client devices - only the pre-generated map tiles are sent. This way, "(a) The complexity of the 3D city model data is decoupled from data transfer complexity (b) the implementation of client applications is simplified significantly as 3D rendering is encapsulated on server side (c) 3D city models can be easily deployed for and used by a large number of concurrent users, leading to a high degree of scalability of the overall approach." <ref>J. Klimke et al.: "Scalable Multi-Platform Distribution of Spatial 3D Contents". ISPRS 8th 3D GeoInfo Conference & WG II/2 Workshop 27–29 November 2013, Istanbul, Turkey, (U. Isikdag, ed.), vol. II-2/W1, ISPRS Annals, ISPRS, pp. 193-200, 2013.</ref>
== Applications == 3D city models can be used for a multitude of purposes in a growing number of different application domains.<ref> {{cite journal |year=2015 |title=Applications of 3D City Models: State of the Art Review |journal=ISPRS International Journal of Geo-Information |volume=4 |issue=4 |pages=2842–2889 |doi=10.3390/ijgi4042842 |last1=Biljecki |first1=F. |last2=Stoter |first2=J. |last3=Ledoux |first3=H. |last4=Zlatanova |first4=S.|author4-link= Sisi Zlatanova |last5=Çöltekin |first5=A. }}</ref> Examples:
* [[Navigation system]]s: 3D navigation maps have become omnipresent both in automotive and pedestrian navigation systems, which include 3D city models, in particular, terrain models and 3D building models, to enhance the visual depiction and to simplify the recognition of locations.<ref>M. Vaaraniemi et al.: ''Intelligent Prioritization and Filtering of Labels in Navigation Maps''. Journal of WSCG, 2014.</ref> * [[Urban Planning]] and [[Architecture]]: To set up, analyze, and disseminate urban planning concepts and projects, 3D city models serve as communication and participation medium.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.mit.edu/ebj/www/JPER.pdf |title=E. Ben-Joseph et al.: ''Urban simulation and the luminous planning table: Bridging the gap between the digital and the tangible''. Journal of Planning Education and Research 21 (2), 196-203, 2001.}}</ref> 3D city models provide means for project communication, better acceptance of development projects through visualization, and therefore avoid monetary loss through project delays; they also help to prevent planning errors.<ref>http://www.gsdi.org/gsdiconf/gsdi12/slides/2.4a.pdf</ref> * [[Spatial Data Infrastructure]]s (SDIs): 3D city models extend spatial data infrastructures and support the management, storage, and usage of 3D models within SDIs; they require not only tools and processes for the initial construction and storage of 3D city models but also have to provide efficient data management and data distribution to support workflows and applications.<ref>http://virtualcitysystems.de/images/pdf/3d-gdi/EN_3D_SDI_2013_Flyer.pdf</ref> * [[GIS]]: GIS support 3D geodata and provide computational algorithms to construct, transform, validate, and analyze 3D city model components. * [[Emergency Management]]: For emergency, risk, and disaster management systems, 3D city models provide the computational framework. In particular, they serve to simulate fire, floodings, and explosions For example, the DETORBA project aims at simulating and analyzing effects of explosion in urban areas at high precision to support prediction of effects for the structural integrity and soundness of the urban infrastructure and safety preparations of rescue forces.<ref>http://virtualcitysystems.de/en/references.html#research {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531173221/http://virtualcitysystems.de/en/references.html#research |date=2014-05-31 }} DETORBA</ref> * [[Spatial Analysis]]: 3D city models provide the computational framework for 3D spatial analysis and simulation. For example, they can be used to compute solar potential for 3D roof surfaces of cities,<ref>C. Carneiro et al.: ''[https://dspace.mit.edu/openaccess-disseminate/1721.1/101640 Solar radiation over the urban texture: LiDAR data and image processing techniques for environmental analysis at city scale]''. 3D Geo-Information Sciences, 319-340, 2008.</ref> visibility analysis within the urban space,<ref>J. Engel, J. Döllner: ''Approaches Towards Visual 3D Analysis for Digital Landscapes and Its Applications''. Digital Landscape Architecture Proceedings 2009, pp. 33-41, 2009.</ref> noise simulation,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://v3d2.tu-bs.de/CGV/People/people/Lancelle/3dcitymodels/3DCityModels_Lancelle_IVCNZ04_final.pdf |title=M. Lancelle and D. Fellner, "Current Issues on 3D City Models," Proc. Image and Vision Computing, 2004, pp. 363–369 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[thermographic inspection]]s of buildings<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?arnumber=05764710 |title=D. Iwaszczuk et al.: ''Matching of 3D building models with IR images for texture extraction.'' JURSE 2011 - Joint Urban Remote Sensing Event, 25-28}}</ref><ref>L. Hoegner et al.: ''Automatic extraction of textures from infrared image sequences and database integration for 3D building models''. PFG Photogrammetrie Fernerkundung Geoinformation, 2007(6): 459-468, 2007.</ref> * [[Geodesign]]: In geodesign, virtual 3D models of the environment (e.g., landscape models or urban models) facilitate exploration and presentation as well as analysis and simulation. * [[Video Game|Gaming]]: 3D city models can be used to obtain base data for virtual 3D scenes used in online and video games. * [[Cultural Heritage]]: 3D city model tools and systems are applied for modeling, design, exploration, and analysis tasks in the scope of cultural heritage. For example, archeological data can be embedded in 3D city models.<ref>M. Trapp et al.: ''Colonia 3D - Communication of Virtual 3D Reconstructions in Public Spaces.'' International Journal of Heritage in the Digital Era (IJHDE), vol. 1, no. 1, pp. 45-74, 2012.</ref> * City Information Systems: 3D city models represent the framework for interactive 3D city information systems and 3D city maps. For example, municipalities apply 3D city models as centralized information platform for location marketing.<ref>http://www.businesslocationcenter.de/en/berlin-economic-atlas/the-project</ref> * [[Property Management]]: 3D city model technology can extend systems and applications used in real-estate and property management. * [[Intelligent Transportation Systems]]: 3D city models can be applied to intelligent transportation systems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ewh.ieee.org/tc/its/index.html |title=IEEE Intelligent Transportation Systems Society}}</ref> * [[Augmented Reality]]: 3D city models can be used as reference frame for augmented reality applications.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cgit.nutn.edu.tw:8080/cgit/PaperDL/CUC_100903141536.PDF |title=C. Portalés et al.: ''Augmented reality and photogrammetry: A synergy to visualize physical and virtual city environments''. ISPRS J. Photogramm. Remote Sensing, 65, 134-142, 2010.}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.virtualcitysystems.com/en 3D City Model Systems and Tools] Management and infrastructure components for 3D city models. * [http://www.3dcontentlogistics.com Map-based Visualization of 3D City Models] Components for 3d city model applications. * [http://www.opengeospatial.org/projects/initiatives/3dpie OGC 3D Portrayal IE] 3D portrayal interoperability experiment of the Open Geospatial Consortium. * [http://www.hpi.uni-potsdam.de/doellner/projects/berlin3d.html 3D City Model of Berlin] Example of a massive 3D city models for an urban area. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140531123815/http://www.hpi.uni-potsdam.de/doellner/projects/interactive_3d_visualization_of_roman_cologne.html 3D City Model of Roman Cologne] Example of a 3D city model for cultural heritage applications.
[[Category:Geographic information systems]] [[Category:Geodesy]] [[Category:Information systems]] [[Category:Earth sciences graphics software]] [[Category:Geographic data and information]]

{{Location map many | World | float = right | caption = The 45×90 points on a world map | coordinates1= {{coord|45|N|90|E}} | coordinates2= {{coord|45|N|90|W}} | coordinates3= {{coord|45|S|90|E}} | coordinates4= {{coord|45|S|90|W}} }} [[File:Sign for the Western Hemisphere's 45X90 point.jpg|thumb|right|The original marker for the 45×90 point in North America; the sign was later amended to explain that the real location is actually approximately {{convert|1063|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} behind and to the left of the marker on the ground.]] [[File:Marker for the Western Hemisphere's 45X90 point (2).jpg|thumb|right|Close up of the incorrectly placed marker in [[Marathon County, Wisconsin]], [[United States]]]] The '''45×90 points''' are the four points on earth which are halfway between the [[geographical pole]]s, the [[equator]], the [[Prime Meridian]], and the [[180th meridian]].
==45°N, 90°W== The best-known and most frequently visited such point is {{coord|45|0|0|N|90|0|0|W}} which is located on land at {{convert|1345|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} above sea level in the town of [[Rietbrock, Wisconsin]] near the unincorporated community of [[Poniatowski, Wisconsin|Poniatowski]]. An incorrect geographic marker was placed there by the [[Marathon County, Wisconsin|Marathon County]] Park Commission, but in 2017, it was removed and relocated to the actual location<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/45-x-90-geographical-marker|title=45 X 90 Geographical Marker|website=Atlas Obscura|language=en|access-date=2017-11-04}}</ref>. It re-opened September 12, 2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://images.google.com/imgres?imgurl=https://assets.atlasobscura.com/media/W1siZiIsInVwbG9hZHMvcGxhY2VfaW1hZ2VzL2FyYTJucm9pZnNiMGQ3ZGVjMTM1ZjAyNzIyZjlfQ2FtZXJhWk9PTS0yMDE3MDcwMjEyMzYzNzU3OV9jb3B5LmpwZyJdLFsicCIsInRodW1iIiwieDM5MD4iXSxbInAiLCJjb252ZXJ0IiwiLXF1YWxpdHkgODEgLWF1dG8tb3JpZW50Il1d/CameraZOOM-20170702123637579_copy.jpg&imgrefurl=https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/45-x-90-geographical-marker&docid=Uff-hl9HleZk0M&tbnid=CMlZT2G8oL2RhM:&vet=1&w=693&h=390&source=sh/x/im|title=Redirect Notice|website=images.google.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-04}}</ref>.
The point has become something of a pop culture phenomenon thanks to Gesicki's Tavern in the tiny cluster of establishments in Poniatowski.<ref name="gesicki">{{cite web|first=Bill |last=Hart |title=Gesicki, John Raymond |url=http://www.marathoncountyhistory.org/PeopleDetails.php?PeopleId=778 |publisher=Marathon County Historical Society |accessdate=24 March 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304062527/http://www.marathoncountyhistory.org/PeopleDetails.php?PeopleId=778 |archivedate=4 March 2016 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> They once sold 45×90 [[T-shirt]]s and registered visitors as members of the "45x90 Club".<ref name="gesicki"/> Since 2006, the Wausau/Central Wisconsin Convention & Visitors Bureau has been the holder of the official "45x90 Club" registration book. The book is on loan from the Gesicki family.<ref>{{cite web|title=Center of the Northwest Hemisphere|url=http://www.ci.wausau.wi.us/Home/AboutWausau/AttractionsLandmarks.aspx |work=Attractions & Landmarks|publisher=City of Wausau, Wisconsin|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> Upon becoming a member of the "45x90 Club", the Wausau/Central Wisconsin Convention & Visitors Bureau will give new members a commemorative coin.
==45°N, 90°E== The only other 45×90 point located on land is {{coord|45|0|0|N|90|0|0|E}} which has a height of {{convert|3311|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} above sea level and is located in a desolate region of the [[Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region]] of [[China]] near the [[Mongolia]]n border, some {{convert|240|km|abbr=on}} northeast of [[Ürümqi]]. Administratively, it is on the border of [[Qitai County|Qitai]] and [[Qinggil County|Qinggil]] Counties. Greg Michaels, an American, and Ru Rong Zhao, a taxi driver from the closest town of [[Qitai County|Qitai]], itself 110 km to the south-southwest, visited this point on April 13, 2004 and documented the visit on the [[Degree Confluence Project]].<ref>{{cite web|title=45°N 90°E|url=http://www.confluence.org/confluence.php?id=6993|publisher=[[Degree Confluence Project]]|accessdate=24 March 2014|date=13 April 2004}}</ref> Their visit shows that there is no monument or any physical sign that recognition has been given to this location.
==45°S, 90°E== [[File:MH370_SIO_search.png|thumb|400px|Possible debris from [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 370]] (colored spots in lower left) were spotted by satellite near 45°S, 90°E.]]
Located in the southern [[Indian Ocean]], {{coord|45|0|0|S|90|0|0|E}} has an ocean floor depth of {{convert|10,489|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} below sea level and is {{convert|773|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} southeast of the nearest uninhabited island of [[Île Saint-Paul]], {{convert|920|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} northeast of [[Elephant Spit]] on [[Heard Island and McDonald Islands|Heard Island]], {{convert|975|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} east north east of [[Port aux Français]] in the [[Kerguelen Islands]], {{convert|1507|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} north of [[Antarctica]], {{convert|1521|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} southwest of the closest inhabited land of [[Augusta, Western Australia]], {{convert|2535|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} southeast of [[Réunion]] Island, and {{convert|3450|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} southeast of [[Benguerra Island]], Mozambique, and {{convert|3600|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} southeast of [[Mossel Bay]], [[South Africa]].
The [[Antipodes|antipode]] of the southern Indian Ocean location is the (45°N,90°W) location in Wisconsin.
In March 2014, the location in the southern Indian Ocean was the subject of an aerial search for the missing [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 370]], after potential debris were spotted by satellite centered on the 45°S, 90°E location.<ref>{{cite news|title=Malaysia plane search: China checks new 'debris' image|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-26697048|accessdate=24 March 2014|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=22 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Murdoch|first=Lindsay|title=Missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370: Floating debris spotted by Chinese satellite image|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/missing-malaysia-airlines-flight-mh370-floating-debris-spotted-by-chinese-satellite-image-20140322-35ap6.html|accessdate=24 March 2014|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=22 March 2014}}</ref>
== 45°S, 90°W== Located in the southern [[Pacific Ocean]], {{convert|806|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} west south west of [[Guaitecas]] in [[Chile]], and {{convert|1910|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} north of Antarctica, {{coord|45|0|0|S|90|0|0|W}} has an ocean floor depth of {{convert|13,730|ft|m|abbr=on|order=flip}} below sea level.
The antipode of the southern Pacific Ocean location is the (45°N,90°E) location in China.
==See also== *[[Degree Confluence Project]] (DCP) *[[45th parallel north]] *[[45th parallel south]] *[[90th meridian east]] *[[90th meridian west]]

{{Unreferenced|date=January 2011}} The '''''Africa Specialty Group''''' is one of many specialty groups within the [[Association of American Geographers]]. The group is composed of academic [[geographers]] with research interests in [[Africa]]. This group publishes the [[African Geographical Review]], a peer-reviewed [[academic journal]].
==External links== {{Sister project links|Africa Specialty Group}}

{{Good article}} [[File:Diagram of Holland Channel cable.png|thumb|300px|right|A period depiction of the Ambrose Channel pilot cable in action.<ref>{{Harvnb|Bond|1920}}.</ref>]]
The '''Ambrose Channel pilot cable''', also called the '''Ambrose Channel leader cable''', was a cable laid in [[Ambrose Channel]] at the entrance to the [[Port of New York and New Jersey]] that provided an audio tone for guiding ships in and out of port at times of low visibility. The cable was laid during 1919 and 1920; it had been removed from the channel and replaced by wireless technology by the end of the 1920s. <!-- Note: this image needs 500px as it has detail which gets blurred out at lower resolution. -->
==Background== [[Ambrose Channel]] is the only shipping channel in and out of the [[Port of New York and New Jersey]], an important [[commercial port]]. Delays posed a major problem for shipping en route to [[New York City]], and bad weather could close the channel for days. Ships were forced to wait at the harbor's entrance for conditions to clear. These delays cost shipping companies substantial amounts of money, with each ship costing between $500 and $4000 per hour it was stopped (roughly $5,700 to $46,000 in 2013 dollars).<ref>{{Harvnb|Wilhelm|1922|p=249 }}.</ref>
==Description and operation== [[File:Ambrose pilot cable cross section.png|thumb|The Cable was composed of several layers.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921b|p=280}}</ref>]]The Ambrose leader cable was an armored cable with a single internal conductor (see picture) that acted like a long radio antenna laid on the channel floor. It originated at [[Fort Lafayette]] (near the present day [[Verrazano-Narrows Bridge]]), then extended 16 miles down the [[Ambrose Channel]] to the vicinity of [[Lightship Ambrose]] offshore.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|pp=44–45}}.</ref> It was powered by a generator at Fort Lafayette that produced 500 [[hertz|Hz]] (cycles per second) current at 400 volts, resulting in an alternating electromagnetic field along the length of the cable that could be detected to approximately a thousand yards away.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|p=51}}. Other voltages may have been used in subsequent operation.</ref> The current was mechanically keyed to send the word "NAVY" in [[Morse Code]].<ref>{{Harvnb|New York Times|1920|p=6}}.</ref>
A ship received by a pair of [[induction coil]]s hung on opposite sides of the ship, and fed through an amplifier into a headset (see diagram, below). By switching between coils, the relative strength of the signal on each side could be compared. The ship maintained a course parallel to the cable by maneuvering to keep the signal strength constant.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|pp=46–47}}.</ref>
==Research and development== [[File:SE 1600 amplifier ckt.png|thumb|200px|Two-stage vacuum-tube amplifier alternately takes input from inductance coils (top) hung on each side of ship.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|p=36}}.</ref>]] The pilot cable required a series of prior discoveries and inventions. In 1882, A. R. Sennett patented the use of a submerged electrical cable to communicate with a ship at a fixed location. Around the same time Charles Stevenson patented a means of navigating ships over an electrically charge cable using a [[galvanometer]]. The method became practical when Earl Hanson adapted early [[vacuum tube]] circuits to amplify the signal.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|p=34}}; {{Harvnb|Current History|1921|p=161}}</ref>
[[Robert H. Marriott]] was a radio pioneer employed by the Navy in [[Puget Sound]], where he conducted early experiments with underwater pilot cables.<ref>{{Harvnb|Geselowitz|2009}}; {{Harvnb|Marriott|1924}}; {{Harvnb|Woods|1980|p=523}}.</ref> His results were sufficiently promising that he recommended further development to Commander Stanford C. Hooper.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wilhelm|1922|p=250 }}</ref> In October, 1919 Commander Hooper instructed A. Crossley, an expert radio aid, to develop and test the concept on a larger scale at the [[Naval Submarine Base New London#History|New London Naval Base]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Wilhelm|1922|p=250 }}.</ref> Crossley installed a longer version of the cable that Marriott had designed. He used a wooden hulled [[launch (ship)|launch]] for the first round of tests before moving to a steel-hulled [[submarine]] for later tests.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wilhelm|1922|p=250 }}.</ref> Both types of vessel picked up the signal and followed the underwater test cable without problem.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wilhelm|1922|p=250 }}.</ref>
==Installation and testing== [[File:Ambrose Channel pilot cable in action.PNG|frame|left|Commander R. F. McConnell on the USS ''Semmes'' with the "Hanson apparatus".<ref>{{Harvnb|Nautical Gazette|1920}}</ref>]] Following the successful tests at New London, the Navy proceeded to large scale testing in Ambrose Channel late in 1919. The [[Minelayer#Naval minelayers|minelayer]] ''Ord'' laid a pilot cable composed of 2,000 feet of leaded and armored cable, 2,000 feet of leaded cable, and 83,000 feet of standard rubber-insulated cable.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|pp=38–39 }}.</ref> The [[USS O'Brien (DD-51)|USS ''O'Brien'']] was fitted with receiving equipment and attempted to follow the cable out of the channel. Unfortunately, it was unable to detect a signal past the 1,000 foot mark, where a break in the cable had prevented the signal from continuing.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|p=40 }}.</ref> The break in the cable was repaired, but over the course of the winter of 1919-1920, crews found that the cable had broken in a total of fifty-two different places due to the strain placed on it while it was being laid. The damage was irreparable.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|p=40 }}; {{Harvnb|Wilhelm|1922|p=250 }}.</ref> Going back to the drawing board, engineers tested 150-foot segments of three different types of cable and used the results to design a new full-size pilot cable.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|pp=40–41}}.</ref> The Navy ordered 87,000 feet of cable from the Simplex Wire and Cable Company in Boston.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|p=42}}.</ref>
Once complete, the cable was loaded onto the [[USS Pequot (ID-2998)|USS ''Pequot'']] in the [[Boston Navy Yard]]. The ship arrived in New York on July 31, 1920.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|p=43 }}.</ref> Ambrose Channel was already crossed by three telegraph cables, owned by [[Western Union]], the [[United States Army|Army]], and the [[New York City Police Department|police]], all of which had to be raised to the surface so the pilot cable could be laid underneath them.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|p=43 }}.</ref> The installation of the cable was completed on August 6, 1920,<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|pp=38–39 }}; {{Harvnb|New York Times|1920|p=6}}.</ref> and by August 28, electrical tests showed that both the sending and receiving circuits were functioning properly.<ref>{{Harvnb|Los Angeles Times|1920}}.</ref> The Navy tested the cable using the seagoing tug [[USS Algorma (AT-34)|USS ''Algorma'']]. It then invited "representatives of various radio companies, shipping interests, [[Maritime pilot|pilots']] associations, governmental bureaus, naval attaches, and others" for a public demonstration on board the destroyer [[USS Semmes (DD-189)|USS ''Semmes'']] from October 6 through October 9.<ref>{{Harvnb|Crossley|1921a|p=290}}.</ref> The ship's windows were covered with canvas and the captains took turns navigating using only the audio cues from the cable.<ref>{{Harvnb|New York Times|1920|p=6}}.</ref>
The cable was well received. Even before the New London tests, the Washington Post called it "the greatest development in marine travel since the invention of the steam turbine"<ref>{{Harvnb|Washington Post|1919|p=21}}.</ref> and the Los Angeles Times declared the technology to be "one of the greatest peacetime gifts that science has devised."<ref>{{Harvnb|Los Angeles Times|1919}}.</ref> Once operational, the latter newspaper called it "the greatest safeguard devised for shipping in modern history".<ref>{{Harvnb|Los Angeles Times|1920}}.</ref> According to a 1921 trade magazine, leader cables had five functions: "to enable a ship to make a good landfall in thick weather, to lead a ship up the harbor, to lead a ship from open water through a restricted channel to open water on the far side, to give warning of outlying dangers, and to assist a vessel to keep a straight course from port to port and thus save fuel."<ref>{{Harvnb|Bennett|1921|p=951}}.</ref> In 1922, the publication ''Radio World'' stated that the cable's first two years of operation had been successful.<ref>{{Harvnb|Gordon|1922|p=72}}.</ref> Also in 1922, ''Radio Broadcast'' boasted about the money saved by the cable as well as the ease of using it.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wilhelm|1922|p=249 }}.</ref> The cable itself was paid for using public funds, but it was the responsibility of ship owners to outfit their vessels with receiving equipment. Installation of the cable cost roughly $50,000<ref>{{Harvnb|Wilhelm|1922|p=249 }}.</ref> and the listening apparatus installed on each ship using the channel cost $1,200,<ref>{{Harvnb|New York Times|1920|p=6}}.</ref> compared with hourly costs of delays that ranged from $500 to $4,000.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wilhelm|1922|p=249 }}.</ref> ''Radio Broadcast'' expressed the belief that navigation cables would become common for both ships and aircraft: "...there is a future for the audio cable... Its fullest usefulness at American ports and elsewhere waits, however, on that large appreciation of radio devices for sea as well as air navigation which pilots, both on the sea and in the air, expect, but do not as yet demand."<ref>{{Harvnb|Wilhelm|1922|p=251}}.</ref>
== Obsolescence and legacy == Despite the media hype, it appears that the Ambrose Channel pilot cable never met with large scale commercial success. Initially, some contemporaries of the cable proposed that it be extended several miles past the Ambrose light.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wilhelm|1922|p= }}.</ref> Such plans never came to fruition, as advances in technology rendered the pilot cable obsolete. By 1929 the ''Baltimore Sun'' reported ships navigating the Channel blindly without making any reference to the cable.<ref>{{Harvnb|Baltimore Sun|1929}}; {{Harvnb|Putnam|1924|p=215}}; {{Harvnb|Science|1924|p=xiv}}.</ref> In that year, Marriott publicly complained that navigation cables still had unrealized potential for guiding ships. <ref>{{Harvnb|Science News-Letter|1929}}.</ref>
Leader cable systems appear to have been made obsolete by the refinement of [[radio direction finding]] and the placement of [[Electric beacon|radio beacons]] (low-power radio transmitters) at strategic locations. Those beacons are analogous to lighthouses, but can be "seen" in all weather, and are used for navigation in the same way as regular lighthouses. The first successful application of these radio beacons as "radio fog signals" were three stations installed near New York in 1921.<ref>{{Harvnb|Putnam|1924}}; {{Harvnb|Radio Broadcast|1922|p=}}.</ref> In 1924, there were eleven stations in operation in the United States and nearly three hundred ships suitably equipped.<ref>{{Harvnb|Putnam|1924|p=213}}.</ref> By 1930, an article in the ''Journal of the [[Royal Society of Arts]]'' declared that "wireless aids and echo sounding have superseded [the leader cable]".<ref>{{Harvnb|Cooper|1930|pp=995–996}}</ref> Today, more modern navigation tools such as [[radar]], [[global positioning system|GPS]], and lighted [[buoy]]<nowiki/>s help ships navigate Ambrose Channel.
Earl Hanson, one of the key players in designing the Ambrose Channel cable, writing for ''Popular Mechanics,'' viewed it as a step toward applying radio cable technology in vast swaths of everyday life, including guiding aircraft and navigating and powering automobiles.<ref>{{Harvnb|Hanson|1934}}; {{Harvnb|Yates|Pacent|1922|p=296}}.</ref> The Ambrose Channel cable was removed from the channel and used in testing an early system of [[autolanding]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Howeth|1963|loc= Chap. 28, [https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uiug.30112064674325;view=1up;seq=367 §16]}}.</ref> The cable found no more success in that role than it did in guiding ships. The [[Blind Landing Experimental Unit]] later tried a similar system briefly before also abandoning it in favor of wireless.<ref>{{Harvnb|Wood|1930|p=13 }}; {{Harvnb|Davis|1922|p=5}}; {{Harvnb|Armstrong|1930|pp=1–2}}; {{Harvnb|Perry|2004|p=100}}; {{Harvnb|Hanson|1919|p=489}}; {{Harvnb|Current History|1921|p=162}}.</ref>

[[Taylor & Francis]] | country = | frequency = Quarterly | history = 1928-present | openaccess = | license = | impact = 1.115 | impact-year = 2016 | website =https://www.tandfonline.com/toc/cage20/current | ISSN = 0004-9182 | eISSN = 1465-3311 }} '''''Australian Geographer''''' ('''''The Australian Geographer''''' until 1975) is a quarterly [[peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]] published by the Geographical Society of New South Wales since August 1928.{{sfn|Biddle|Aplin|1996}} Covering all aspects of [[Australian geography]], it is currently copublished with [[Taylor & Francis]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|https://www.tandfonline.com/toc/cage20/current}} ==Further reading== *{{cite journal |last1=Biddle |first1=Don |last2=Aplin |first2=Graeme |date=1996 |title=The Australian geographer, 1928–1996—and beyond |journal=Australian Geographer |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages=5–8 |doi=10.1080/00049189608703153}} [[Category:Taylor & Francis academic journals]] [[Category:Geography journals]] [[Category:Publications established in 1928]] [[Category:English-language journals]] {{australia-stub}} {{geography-journal-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} [[File:Boundary stone Maesglase.jpg|thumb|A [[slate]] boundary stone on [[Maesglase]]]] [[File:D-NW-Bad Salzuflen-Wüsten - Grenzstein (klein) in Pehlen.jpg|thumb|Historical boundary stone between the [[Principality of Lippe]] and the [[Kingdom of Prussia]].]]
A '''boundary marker''', '''border marker''', '''boundary stone''', or '''border stone''' is a robust physical marker that identifies the start of a land [[Border|boundary]] or the change in a boundary, especially a change in direction of a boundary.<ref name="straight-border" /> There are several other types of named border markers, known as '''pillars''', '''obelisks''', and '''corners'''.<ref name="straight-border" /> Border markers can also be markers through which a border line runs in a straight line to determine that border.<ref name="straight-border">{{cite conference | title=AN HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE – Longitude 129 degrees east, and why it is not the longest, straight line in the world | publisher=Eyepiece – Official Organ of The Institution of Surveyors, Australia, W.A. Division | accessdate=15 January 2012 | author=Porter, John | conference=National Perspectives – 32nd Australian Surveyors Congress Technical Papers 31 March – 6 April 1990 | location=Canberra: The Institution | pages=18–24 |date=June 1990}}</ref> They can also be the markers from which a border marker has been fixed.<ref name="straight-border" />
==Purpose == According to Josiah Ober, boundary markers are "a way of imposing human, cultural, social meanings upon a once-undifferentiated natural environment." Boundary markers are linked to social hierarchies, since they derive their meaning from the authority of a person or group to declare the limits of a given space of land for political, social or religious reasons. Ober notes that "determining who can use parcels of arable land and for what purpose, has immediate and obvious economic implications."<ref name=":0">Ober, Josiah. "Greek Horoi: Artifactual Texts and the Contingency of Meaning." ''Methods in the Mediterranean: Historical and Archaeological Views of Texts and Archaeology.'' Ed. David. B. Small. Leiden: Brill, 1995. URL: http://www.stanford.edu/group/dispersed_author/docs/GreekHoroi.pdf</ref>
Many borders were drawn along invisible lines of [[latitude]] or [[longitude]], which often created a need to mark these borders on the ground, as accurately as possible, using the technology of the day.<ref name="straight-border" /> Advances in [[GPS]] technology have shown that there are many borders inaccurately marked on the ground.<ref name="straight-border" />
Boundary markers have often been used to mark critical points{{clarify|date=February 2016}} on political boundaries, i.e. those between countries, [[Federated state|states]] or local administrations, but have also been used to mark out the limits of private landholdings, especially in areas where fences or walls are impractical or unnecessary.{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}}
In developed countries the use of markers for land ownership has in many places been replaced by maps and land ownership registration. Boundary markers are not legal markers in Western countries and may have troublesome legal effects.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fairview-industries.com/gismodule/PartTwoMisplacedBoundary.html |title=Cadastral Information For GIS Specialists - Case Of The Misplaced Boundary Marker |publisher=Fairview-industries.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110921084505/http://www.fairview-industries.com/gismodule/PartTwoMisplacedBoundary.html |archivedate=21 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, boundary markers have legal meaning in [[Japan]], and are generally installed across the country.<ref>[http://ja.wikibooks.org/wiki/%E6%B0%91%E6%B3%95%E7%AC%AC229%E6%9D%A1 Civil Law 229]; [http://www.hiroshima-chousashi.or.jp/kanri/kan0page.htm more information] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130103125854/http://www.hiroshima-chousashi.or.jp/kanri/kan0page.htm |date=3 January 2013 }}</ref> Markers are still used extensively for marking international borders, which are traditionally classified into two categories: natural boundaries, correlating to topographical features such as rivers or mountain ranges, and artificial boundaries, which have no obvious relation to topography. The latter category includes borders defined by boundary markers such as stones and walls.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Settlement of Boundary Disputes in International Law|last = Cukwurah|first = A. Oye|publisher = Manchester University Press|year = 1967|location = Manchester|pages = 16–17}}</ref> International boundary markers are placed and can be maintained by mutual agreement of the bordering countries.
==Construction== Boundary markers, traditionally, were often made of [[Rock (geology)|stone]], but later many have been made with concrete or a mixture of materials.<ref name="kimberley"> {{cite web |url=http://www.kununurra.org.au/research/1921-wa-nt-border-determinations |title=1921 WA-NT Border Determinations |accessdate=9 January 2012 |publisher=Kununurra Historical Society Inc.}}</ref> They are typically placed at a notable or especially visible point. Many are inscribed with relevant information such as the abbreviation of the boundary holder and often a date.<ref name="straight-border" />
== History ==
=== Asia ===
==== China ==== The oldest known boundary stone in China is from Jiangsu Province. Dating from 12 A.D., it bears the inscription "the sea area from Jiaozhou Bay to the east of Guixan county belongs to Langya Shire and the waters from the south of Guixan county to the east of the estuary of Guanhe River belongs to Donghai Shire."<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/regional/2015-05/18/content_20750795.htm|title = The boundary stone of Han Dynasty in Suma Bay - China - Chinadaily.com.cn|last = 潘其|website = www.chinadaily.com.cn|access-date = 2016-03-03}}</ref> More recently, the border between Russia and China was formally demarcated with boundary stones as the result of the Treaty of Kiakhta in 1727.<ref>{{Cite book|title = China Marches West: The Qing Conquest of Central Asia|last = Perdue|first = Peter C.|publisher = Harvard University Press|year = 2009|location = Cambridge, MA|pages = 289}}</ref> In the nineteenth century, stones were used to outline the limits of the International Settlement in Shanghai.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Britain and China, 1840-1970: Empire, Finance and War|author1=Bickers, Robert |author2=Jonathan J. Howlett |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher = Routledge|year = 2015|location = London|pages = 190}}</ref>
==== Thailand ==== In ancient Thailand, sacred boundary stones called ''Sema Hin'' delimited Buddhist temple precincts. In some cases they feature inscriptions recounting the history of the temple;<ref>{{Cite journal |author= Phetsanghan, Phairot |author2= Songkoon Chantachon |author3= Boonsom Yodmalee |last-author-amp= yes|date = 2009|title = Sema Hin Isan, the Origin of the Temple Boundary Stones in Northeast Thailand|url = http://medwelljournals.com/abstract/?doi=sscience.2009.186.190|journal = The Social Sciences |volume=4 |pages=186–190|access-date = March 3, 2016}}</ref> others were carved with wheels of the law,<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = The Art and Architecture of Thailand: From Prehistoric Times Through the Thirteenth Century|last = Woodward|first = Hiram, W.|publisher = Brill|year = 2003|location = Leiden|pages = 104}}</ref> while some specimens consist of unfinished stone.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Art and Architecture of Thailand: From Prehistoric Times Through the Thirteenth Century|last = Woodward|first = Hiram W.|publisher = Brill|year = 2003|location = Leiden|pages = 100}}</ref> In addition to temples, ''sema'' could enclose statues of Buddha or sacred mounds.<ref name=":1" />
=== Near East and Africa ===
==== Israel ==== According to B. S. Jackson, stones were put in place in ancient Israel to "mark the boundary of a territory (public or private), and to seek to deter potential violators of that boundary through the use of threats."<ref>{{Cite book|title = The World of Ancient Israel: Sociological, Anthropological and Political Perspectives|editor-last = Clements|editor-first = Ronald E. |publisher = Cambridge University Press|year = 1991|location = Cambridge|pages = 190}}</ref> The Hebrew Bible contains a strict prohibition against the unauthorized displacement or removal of boundary markers.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Settlement of Boundary Disputes in International Law|last = Cukwurah|first = A. Oye|publisher = Manchester University Press|year = 1967|location = Manchester|pages = 10}}</ref>
==== Egypt ==== An example of boundary markers in ancient Egypt were the boundary stelae of Akhenaten. They defined the limits of the sacred city of Akhet-Aten, built by Akhenaten as the center of the Aten religious cult which he founded. Egyptologists categorize the stelae based on whether they are inscribed with the "Earlier Proclamation," a general explanation of why the location was selected and how the city would be designed, or the "Later Proclamation," which provides additional details about the perimeters of the city.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Boundary Stelae of Akhenaten|last = Murnane|first = William J.|publisher = Kegan Paul Int.|year = 1993|location = London|pages = 1–2}}</ref>
=== Europe === [[File:German troops crossing the Soviet border.jpg|thumb|upright|German troops at the Soviet state border marker during [[Operation Barbarossa]], 1941]]
==== Finland ==== [[File:Kaavi, Pohjois-Savo.JPG|thumb|upright=0.75|left|A typical roadside border marker in Finland, entering [[Kaavi]] municipality in [[Pohjois-Savo]] region.]] [[Glacial erratic]]s and similar natural stones were often used as boundary markers between properties. Knowledge of their locations was typically maintained by oral tradition, wherein men of each house would walk the length of the border. These stones then became boundary markers for [[Municipalities of Finland|municipalities]], and eventually provinces and countries. For example, Kuhankuono is a stone that marks the [[Quadripoint#Multipoints of greater numerical complexity|multipoint]] border between seven municipalities in [[Kurjenrahka National Park]] near [[Turku]]. Today, however, steel rods topped with a cube painted orange are usually used. Municipalities often post a traffic sign featuring their coat of arms on the border on major roads. On the [[Finnish-Russian border]], many historical border stones, marked with Swedish and Imperial Russian symbols, are still in use. The actual Finnish-Russian border is marked by small white bollard, but on both sides of the border there are large striped bollards decorated with a coat of arms: a blue/white bollard on the Finnish side, a red/green bollard on the Russian side.<ref>http://www.iltalehti.fi/uutiset/2015082320139715_uu.shtml</ref> Artificial cairns are found on the Norway-Russia-Finland tripoint ([[Treriksrøysa]]) and Norway-Sweden-Finland tripoint ([[Three-Country Cairn]]). The Sweden-Finland border on [[Märket]] is marked with holes drilled to the rock, because seasonal [[pack ice]] can shear off any protruding markers. In folklore, a type of [[haltija]], ''rajahaltija'', a kind of a local spirit, was believed to haunt borders that had been unjustly moved.
==== Greece ==== The earliest reference to a boundary stone in Greek literature is in the ''Iliad'', which describes the goddess Athena using one as a projectile. Boundary stones, known as ''horos'', could be made of either carved or undressed stones, and were typically inscribed with the Greek word ''horos''. One such stone was used to indicate the edge of the Athenian ''agora''.<ref name=":0" /> The practice of separating areas of land with boundary stones, though common, was widely considered by classical writers to be a violation of the principle of communal land ownership.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Science and Civilization in China: Volume 2, History of Scientific Thought|last = Needham|first = Joseph|publisher = Cambridge University Press|year = 1956|location = Cambridge|pages = 127}}</ref>
==== Rome ==== In ancient Roman religion, the god [[Terminus (god)|Terminus]] was worshiped as the patron god of boundary markers.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Settlement of International Boundary Disputes in International Law|last = Cukwurah|first = A. Oye|publisher = Manchester University Press|year = 1967|location = Manchester|pages = 11}}</ref> Ovid, in a hymn directed to the god, wrote: "O Terminus, whether thou art a stone or a stump buried in the field, … thou dost set bounds to people and cities and vast kingdoms".<ref>{{Cite book|title = Brown's Boundary Control and Legal Principles|author1=Robillard, Walter G. |author2=Donald A. Wilson |author3=Curtin M. Brown |last-author-amp=yes |publisher = John Wiley|year = 2009|location = Hoboken, NJ|pages = 6}}</ref> Numa Pompillius made the first Roman law requiring boundary stones around private property and instituting capital punishment for anyone found guilty of moving these stones.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Settlement of Boundary Disputes in International Law|last = Cukwurah|first = A. Oye|publisher = Manchester University Press|year = 1967|location = Manchester|pages = 11}}</ref>
==== Monaco ==== In 1828, the [[Monaco|Principality of Monaco]] and the [[Kingdom of Sardinia|Kingdom of Piedmont-Sardinia]] established a physical border with 91 boundary stones, each numbered 1 to 91, running along the border from present-day [[Fontvieille, Monaco|Fontvieille]] to [[Menton|Menton-Garavan]].<ref>http://bornes.frontieres.free.fr/index.htm</ref> Prior to 1848, the Principality of Monaco included the villages of Roquebrune, Monti, Garavan and Menton. Of the original 91 boundary stones only 12 remain: 6 within the [[Monaco|Principality of Monaco]], 3 in [[Roquebrune-Cap-Martin]], and 3 in [[Menton]]. The boundary stones numbered 9, 12, 15, and 31 are located in [[Monaco]]. Another stone has been cast in concrete in the Sainte-Cécile area of [[Monaco]] thus rendering its number illegible. Stone number 55, originally located in [[Roquebrune-Cap-Martin|Roquebrune]], was given as a gift from the city of [[Roquebrune-Cap-Martin|Roquebrune]] to the [[Monaco|Principality of Monaco]] and is now located in [[Monaco]]'s city hall. Stones numbered 56, 57, and 58 are located in [[Roquebrune-Cap-Martin|Roquebrune]]. Stones numbered 62, 71, and 73 are located in [[Menton]]. All the boundary stones have three engraved sides: one side with their individual numbers (1 to 91), one side with the letter "M" indicating [[Monaco]]'s territory, and one side with a cross (+) indicating the Kingdom of Piedmont-Sardinia's territory. The cross represents the coat of arms of the [[House of Savoy]], rulers of Piedmont-Sardinia.
===Western Australia=== The history of [[Western Australia border#Marking the WA border on the ground|marking the Western Australian border on the ground]] states that the "Austral Pillar" and the "Deakin Pillar" are points used to determine their position east of [[Greenwich]] and then fix a border from, in this case used to determine the line of the [[129th meridian east]] [[longitude]], as the [[Western Australia border|Western Australian border]].<ref name="straight-border" /> The Deakin [[Obelisk]] and the Kimberley Obelisk in Australia are used in a slightly different way, in that a line is run north and south through a point on the obelisks, formed by a copper plug embedded into the top centre of the concrete obelisks.<ref name="straight-border" /> The "corners" in Australia, such as [[Cameron Corner Survey Marker|Cameron Corner]], [[Haddon Corner]], [[Poeppel Corner]], and [[Surveyor Generals Corner]], are where multiple borders meet or a border changes direction.<ref name="straight-border" />
=== United States ===
==== Hawaii ==== The basic unit of the ancient Hawaiian land division system was the ''ahupua'a'', a self-sustaining agricultural district.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Hawaii: A History of the Big Island|last = Oaks|first = Robert|publisher = Arcadia Publishing|year = 2003|location = Charleston|pages = 13}}</ref> The places where a road crossed the border of an ''ahupua'a'' were marked with distinctive altars, known as ''ahu'' or (stone) piles. These altars served not only as boundary markers but also as sites for the performance of religious rituals related to land taxation.<ref>{{Cite book|title = A Dictionary of Hawaiian Legal Land Terms|last = Lucas|first = Paul Nahoa|publisher = University of Hawaii Press|year = 1995|location = Honolulu|pages = 4}}</ref> C. J. Lyons, an early surveyor of Hawaii,<ref>{{Cite journal|author1=Gonschor, Lorenz |author2=Kamanamaikalani Beamer |lastauthoramp=yes |title = Toward an Inventory of Ahupua'a in the Hawaiian Kingdom: A survey of Nineteenth and early Twentieth-Century Cartographic and Archival Records of the Island of Hawai'i.|journal = The Hawaiian Journal of History |volume=48 |year=2014}}</ref> recorded that „[u]pon this altar at the annual progress of the akua makahiki (year god) was deposited the tax paid by the land whose boundary it marked, and also an image of a hog, ''puaa'', carved out of kukui wood and stained with red ochre. … [F]rom this came the name, ''ahupuaa''“.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Kingship and Sacrifice: Ritual and Society in Ancient Hawaii|last = Valerio|first = Valeri|publisher = University of Chicago Press|year = 1985|location = Chicago|pages = 155}}</ref> Naturally occurring landscape features were also used as points of reference for district borders.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Land Tenure in the Pacific|last = Crocombe|first = R. G.|publisher = University of the South Pacific|year = 1987|location = Suva Fiji|pages = 26}}</ref>
==== Washington, D.C. ==== The original boundaries of the District of Columbia were marked using boundary stones. These were made of saw-cut sandstone blocks and stood two feet high when set in the ground. Ten boundary stones were placed along each side of the 100 square mile (259 square kilometer) district of Columbia. Although the original surveyors intended each side to be ten miles (16 kilometers) long, their measurements were often inaccurate, resulting in the sometimes significant misplacement of stones and the overall skewing of the District boundaries.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Woodward|first = Fred E.|date = 1907|title = A Ramble Along the Boundary Stones of the District of Columbia with a Camera|journal = Historical Society of Washington, D.C. |pages=63–87}}</ref> Some of these discrepancies are intentional, because the ground at the exact mile point was covered in water; “in such cases,” Andrew Ellicott, the leader of the surveying crew, noted in 1793, “the stones are placed on the nearest firm ground and the true distance in miles and poles is marked on them”.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last = Nye|first = Edwin Darby|date = 1971|title = Revisiting Washington's Forty Boundary Stones|journal = Historical Society of Washington, D.C. |pages=740–51}}</ref>
Information engraved on the stones includes the number (1 through 10) of the stone within the sequence on that side of the District, the date of placement, and the words "Jurisdiction of the United States." In the twentieth century, the Daughters of the American Revolution voluntarily took responsibility for preserving the stones, which had fallen victim to vandalization and urban development.<ref name=":2" /> In the late 1990s renewed interest in the boundary stones led to increased preservation efforts by the DAR and other organizations.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.boundarystones.org|title = Boundary Stones of Washington, D.C.|website = www.boundarystones.org|access-date = 2016-03-03}}</ref>
==== Other States ==== In 1773, a Franciscan friar named Francisco Palou erected the first boundary marker between Alta and Baja California. Commissioned by the Spanish Crown, it consisted of a cross made from alder wood and placed standing upright on a rock.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Hendry|first = George W.|date = 1926|title = Francisco Palou's Boundary Marker|journal = California Historical Society Quarterly |pages=321–27}}</ref> In the British colonies, milestones were shipped from England to mark the Mason–Dixon line.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Boundaries of the United States and the several States: with miscellaneous geographic information concerning areas altitudes and geographic centers|last = Van Zandt|first = Franklin K.|publisher = United States Government Printing Office|year = 1976|pages = 139}}</ref> A block cut from sandstone was placed at the intersection of Wyoming, Colorado and Utah in 1879,<ref>{{Cite book|title = Boundaries of the United States|last = Van Zandt|first = Franklin K.|publisher = United States Government Printing Office|year = 1976|pages = 143}}</ref> and stone posts were used along the western border of South Dakota.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Boundaries of the United States|last = Van Zandt|first = Franklin K.|publisher = United States Government Printing Office|year = 1976|pages = 136}}</ref> Boundaries were occasionally resurveyed and boundary stones replaced or restored, depending on their condition.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Boundaries of the United States|last = Van Zandt|first = Franklin K.|publisher = United States Government Printing Office|year = 1976|pages = 71}}</ref>
== Examples of historic boundary markers == [[Dreieckiger Pfahl]], Germany
==Gallery== <gallery> File:BorderPost272 - Norway and Sweden.jpg|Border stone from 1763 between [[Norway]] and [[Sweden]], located in the [[Arctic]] File:Border stone.JPG|Border stone at [[Passo San Giacomo]] between {{Interlanguage link multi|Val Formazza|it}} in Italy and {{Interlanguage link multi|Val Bedretto|it}} in Switzerland File:2011-02-13-chemin.jpg|Two French-Swiss border boundary markers. File:Boundary Stone (District of Columbia) NE 2.jpg|[[Boundary Markers of the Original District of Columbia|Boundary stone of the original District of Columbia]] set in 1792 marking the boundary between [[Washington, D.C.]], and [[Maryland]] in the [[United States]]. File:Nages Peyre sus autre.JPG|Border stone in France between the communes of [[Nages]], [[Murat-sur-Vèbre]] and [[Fraisse-sur-Agout]] File:Moisburger Stein.JPG|German forest boundary stone set up in 1754; it marks the end of a line of boundary stones between the [[House of Hanover|Hanoverian]] state forest and woods held in common by local farmers. The border was marked in 1750 by order of [[George II of Great Britain]] who was also [[Elector of Hannover]] at that time. File:Grenspaal Obdam en Hensbroek 3.JPG|A boundary marker in [[Obdam]], the Netherlands. It marks the boundary between Obdam and [[Hensbroek]]. File:Banpaal met eenhoorn uit 1761.jpg|Boundary marker (also banishing pole) in [[Schardam]], the Netherlands, showing the [[coat of arms of Hoorn]]. File:Pahang-Selangor Border Stone.jpg|Border stone in [[Mount Nuang]] hiking track. Marks the boundary between [[Selangor]] and [[Pahang]], [[Malaysia]]. File:Modern Boundary Marker Point Roberts.JPG|Modern boundary marker on the [[49th parallel north]] designating the border between the [[United States]] and [[Canada]]. File:State Border of Ukraine.png|Typical border marker of [[Ukraine]]. File:Easternmost finland.jpg|[[Finland–Russia border]] markers: a white marker for the actual border, "guarded" by striped bollards, marked with a coat of arms, maintained by each state.</gallery>
== See also == *[[Bai Sema]], which delimit sacred areas *[[Dreiherrenstein]], historical tripoints of the Holy Roman Empire *[[Milestone]], mile peg or [[kilometre]] sign *[[Survey marker]] *[[Triangulation station]] (Trig Point – Australia/NZ/UK) *[[Tripoint]]
==References== {{Commons category|Boundary stones}} {{Reflist}}
